title: Polar Function - Average Rate of Change

content.question: Let <math alttext="r equals f open parentheses theta close parentheses"><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>θ</mi></mfenced></math> be a polar function with <math alttext="f open parentheses theta close parentheses equals negative 4 sin theta cos open parentheses 2 theta close parentheses"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>θ</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>sin</mi><mi>θ</mi><mi>cos</mi><mfenced><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>. Which of the following is an estimate for <math alttext="r equals f open parentheses 1.5 close parentheses"><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mn>1.5</mn></mfenced></math>, using the average rate of change of <math alttext="r"><mi>r</mi></math> with respect to <math alttext="theta"><mi>θ</mi></math> over the interval <math alttext="open square brackets pi over 6 comma fraction numerator 2 pi over denominator 3 end fraction close square brackets"><mfenced close="]" open="["><mrow><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mo>,</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></math> ?

topic.text: 3.15: Rates of Change in Polar Functions

skill.text: Skill 3.B: Apply numerical results in a given mathematical or applied context.
